member.summary: Adds GleamTech related extensions methods to class for ASP.NET Core support.

member.name: M:GleamTech.AspNet.Core.RazorPageExtensions.RenderHead(Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Razor.RazorPageBase,GleamTech.AspNet.UI.Component,GleamTech.AspNet.UI.Component[])
member.summary: Renders the required resource tags (e.g. JS, CSS includes etc.) for one or more GleamTech components. This method should be called inside <head> tag of the page. If you call this method inside <body> tag or some random place, the browser would misbehave. If you are rendering multiple GleamTech components in the same page, call this method once by passing all the component instances at once, this way the resources shared by all the components will be merged and included in the page once. Make sure you are not calling this method multiple times and adding the result to the same page HTML, for example including the same JS file multiple times in the same page would cause browser errors.
member.param: The instance.
The GleamTech component instance to render the head for.
Other GleamTech component instances to render the head for which are on the same page.
member.returns: The component resource tags that goes into <head> tag of the page.

member.name: M:GleamTech.AspNet.Core.RazorPageExtensions.RenderHeadWithoutJs(Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Razor.RazorPageBase,GleamTech.AspNet.UI.Component,GleamTech.AspNet.UI.Component[])
member.summary: Renders the required resource tags except JS includes (only CSS includes etc.) for one or more GleamTech components. This method can be preferred when you want to render only CSS includes inside <head> tag and render only JS includes at the bottom of the page before before the closing </body> tag via calling . This practice of having CSS includes <head> and JS includes at the bottom before the closing </body> tag, is for increasing browser loading and rendering of your whole page; i.e. the user sees your page with your styles at first glance while the JS files are being loaded in the background. This method should be called inside <head> tag of the page. If you call this method inside <body> tag or some random place, the browser would misbehave. If you are rendering multiple GleamTech components in the same page, call this method once by passing all the component instances at once, this way the resources shared by all the components will be merged and included in the page once. Make sure you are not calling this method multiple times and adding the result to the same page HTML, for example including the same JS file multiple times in the same page would cause browser errors.
member.param: The instance.
The GleamTech component instance to render the head for.
Other GleamTech component instances to render the head for which are on the same page.
member.returns: The component resource tags that goes into <head> tag of the page.

member.name: M:GleamTech.AspNet.Core.RazorPageExtensions.RenderJs(Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Razor.RazorPageBase,GleamTech.AspNet.UI.Component,GleamTech.AspNet.UI.Component[])
member.summary: Renders the required resource tags of JS includes (no CSS includes etc.) for one or more GleamTech components. This method can be preferred when you want to render only JS includes at the bottom of the page before before the closing </body> tag and render only CSS includes inside <head> tag via calling . This practice of having CSS includes <head> and JS includes at the bottom before the closing </body> tag, is for increasing browser loading and rendering of your whole page; i.e. the user sees your page with your styles at first glance while the JS files are being loaded in the background. This method should be called at the bottom of the page before before the closing </body> tag. If you call this method at some random place, the browser would misbehave. If you are rendering multiple GleamTech components in the same page, call this method once by passing all the component instances at once, this way the resources shared by all the components will be merged and included in the page once. Make sure you are not calling this method multiple times and adding the result to the same page HTML, for example including the same JS file multiple times in the same page would cause browser errors.
member.param: The instance.
The GleamTech component instance to render the JS includes for.
Other GleamTech component instances to render the JS includes for which are on the same page.
member.returns: The component resource tags that goes at the bottom of the page before before the closing </body> tag.

member.name: M:GleamTech.AspNet.Core.RazorPageExtensions.RenderBody(Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Razor.RazorPageBase,GleamTech.AspNet.UI.Component)
member.summary: Renders the actual body tags for a GleamTech component. This method should be called inside <body> tag (or child tags) of the page. If you call this method inside <head> tag or some random place, the browser would misbehave. If you are rendering multiple GleamTech components in the same page, this method can be called separately for each component.
member.param: The instance.
The GleamTech component instance to render the component body for.
member.returns: The component body tags that goes into <body> tag (or child tags) of the page.

member.name: T:GleamTech.AspNet.DistributedStateMode
member.summary: Defines the distributed state mode to use for components.

member.name: F:GleamTech.AspNet.DistributedStateMode.Auto
member.summary:
Distributed state should be used when necessary, i.e. serialization of state objects to session is done only if your application is configured to use distributed session. This is the default.
If your application is configured to use in-process (not distributed) session, uses MemoryCache for performance reasons. This way we can avoid unnecessary serialization of state objects to session which can cause overhead for requests.
If your application is configured to use distributed session, uses distributed session, i.e. serializes state objects to session so that state is available for cloud or multi-server environment.
Distributed session meaning: If session state mode is InProc for ASP.NET Classic or MemoryDistributedCache is set for ASP.NET Core, then session is in-process (not distributed). In other cases, session is distributed.

member.name: F:GleamTech.AspNet.DistributedStateMode.Always
member.summary: Distributed state should always be used, i.e serialization of state objects to session is forced even if your application is configured to use in-process (not distributed) session. This is useful for testing and debugging purposes, e.g. testing serialization locally before deploying to cloud or multi-server environment.

member.name: F:GleamTech.AspNet.DistributedStateMode.Never
member.summary: Distributed state should never be used, i.e serialization of state objects to session is disabled even if your application is configured to use distributed session. Note that you will get "state not found" errors if you have more than one instance of your application.

member.name: P:GleamTech.AspNet.GleamTechWebConfiguration.CacheMaxAge
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that specifies the maximum amount of time to consider a cached item fresh and keep it stored in the cache. Cached items older than this age will be removed when the cache trimming (clean up) runs (when auto trim is run or when Trim method is manually called). The default value is 90 days. In string representation, value in format "d" is considered days (e.g. "30" is 30 days) and value in format "hh:mm" is considered hours and minutes (e.g. "1:30" is 1 hour and 30 minutes). Note that "24:00" would mean 24 days as hour range is 0 to 23 and minute range is 0 to 59. See documentation for details on possible string representations.

member.name: P:GleamTech.AspNet.GleamTechWebConfiguration.CacheWaitTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that specifies the maximum amount of time to wait for a cached item to be available (wait for a file lock from other threads or processes to become available, i.e. wait for an ongoing caching of the same file to complete) before giving up on the cache request. The default value is 5 minutes. In string representation, value in format "d" is considered days (e.g. "30" is 30 days) and value in format "hh:mm" is considered hours and minutes (e.g. "1:30" is 1 hour and 30 minutes). Note that "24:00" would mean 24 days as hour range is 0 to 23 and minute range is 0 to 59. See documentation for details on possible string representations.

member.name: P:GleamTech.AspNet.GleamTechWebConfiguration.CacheAutoTrimInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that specifies the interval to run automatic cache trimming (clean up). Cached items older than will be removed when the cache is trimmed. If the value is 0 or negative, the auto trim is disabled. The default value is 20 minutes. In string representation, value in format "d" is considered days (e.g. "30" is 30 days) and value in format "hh:mm" is considered hours and minutes (e.g. "1:30" is 1 hour and 30 minutes). Note that "24:00" would mean 24 days as hour range is 0 to 23 and minute range is 0 to 59. See documentation for details on possible string representations.

member.summary: Gets the reource cache used by this web configuration instance.
member.returns: A instance.

member.name: P:GleamTech.AspNet.GleamTechWebConfiguration.CookieSameSiteFixEnabled
member.summary:
Gets or sets a value that specifies whether SameSite fix should be used for session cookies and other cookies that GleamTech emits. The default is false.
You don't need to use this property when is or .
If you open a GleamTech component in an iframe with a cross-domain URL, recent browsers will not allow the session cookie to be set inside iframe due to default security settings (could be overridden in your browser) and the component will fail to find the existing session from the server. When enabled, by default SameSiteMode.None will be used for the cookies.
Note that Chrome 80+ allows SameSiteMode.None only if the cookie is also marked Secure and we will mark it Secure when the request is secure (HTTPS). So even with this fix if your cross-domain URL is not HTTPS, Chrome 80+ still does not allow the cookie in cross domain iframe (with default browser settings). Fix works on IE and Firefox even if your cross-domain URL is not HTTPS. Also, the fix can only work when your application is running on ASP.NET 4.7.2+ runtime (not target framework but deployment machine runtime) or ASP.NET Core runtime.

member.name: P:GleamTech.AspNet.GleamTechWebConfiguration.CookielessSessionMode
member.summary:
Gets or sets a value that specifies whether cookieless session should be used to automatically fix session issues, i.e. when the browser does not allow cookies via browser settings or via iframe with a cross-domain URL. The cookieless session will be established via headers, form or querystring where possible. The default is .
Cookie support is detected on the browser via JS with . In some cases (e.g. Cordova WebView), the detection may not be reliable, in that case you can use .
You don't need to use when this property is true.

member.name: P:GleamTech.AspNet.GleamTechWebConfiguration.CookielessSessionParameter
member.summary:
Gets or sets a value that specifies the parameter name to use for cookieless session which will be used in headers, form or querystring where possible. The default is "sid-gt".
It is not recommended to change it unless you have a conflict in your web application (e.g. if you already have a querystring named "sid-gt").

member.name: P:GleamTech.AspNet.GleamTechWebConfiguration.DistributedStateMode
member.summary:
Gets or sets a value that specifies whether distributed state should be used for components. The default is .
In mode, serialization of state objects to session is done only if your application is configured to use distributed session:
If your application is configured to use in-process (not distributed) session, uses MemoryCache for performance reasons. This way we can avoid unnecessary serialization of state objects to session which can cause overhead for requests.
If your application is configured to use distributed session, uses distributed session, i.e. serializes state objects to session so that state is available for cloud or multi-server environment.
Distributed session meaning: If session state mode is InProc for ASP.NET Classic or MemoryDistributedCache is set for ASP.NET Core, then session is in-process (not distributed). In other cases, session is distributed.
In mode, serialization of state objects to session is forced even if your application is configured to use in-process (not distributed) session. This is useful for testing and debugging purposes, e.g. testing serialization locally before deploying to cloud or multi-server environment.
In mode, serialization of state objects to session is disabled even if your application is configured to use distributed session. Note that you will get "state not found" errors if you have more than one instance of your application.

member.name: P:GleamTech.AspNet.GleamTechWebConfiguration.LocklessSessionFixEnabled
member.summary:
Gets or sets a value that specifies whether lockless session fix for ASP.NET Classic should be used. The default is false.
ASP.NET Classic and ASP.NET Core both save session at the end of the request. In addition ASP.NET Classic locks the request when session in ReadWrite mode unlike ASP.NET Core. So consequent requests keep waiting until the request with the lock is completed. This lock also effects InProc session provider, not only distributed ones. With this fix, session lock is disabled internally to improve performance.

member.name: T:GleamTech.AspNet.Multipart.MultipartParser
member.summary:
Provides methods to parse a
multipart/form-data
stream into it's parameters and file data.

remarks.para: A parameter is defined as any non-file data passed in the multipart stream. For example any form fields would be considered a parameter.

The parser determines if a section is a file or not based on the presence or absence of the filename argument for the Content-Type header. If filename is set then the section is assumed to be a file, otherwise it is assumed to be parameter data.

member.name: T:GleamTech.AspNet.Mvc.WebViewPageExtensions
member.summary: Adds GleamTech related extensions methods to class for ASP.NET MVC support.

member.name: M:GleamTech.AspNet.Mvc.WebViewPageExtensions.RenderHead(System.Web.Mvc.WebViewPage,GleamTech.AspNet.UI.Component,GleamTech.AspNet.UI.Component[])
member.summary: Renders the required resource tags (e.g. JS, CSS includes etc.) for one or more GleamTech components. This method should be called inside <head> tag of the page. If you call this method inside <body> tag or some random place, the browser would misbehave. If you are rendering multiple GleamTech components in the same page, call this method once by passing all the component instances at once, this way the resources shared by all the components will be merged and included in the page once. Make sure you are not calling this method multiple times and adding the result to the same page HTML, for example including the same JS file multiple times in the same page would cause browser errors.
member.param: The instance.
The GleamTech component instance to render the head for.
Other GleamTech component instances to render the head for which are on the same page.
member.returns: The component resource tags that goes into <head> tag of the page.

member.name: M:GleamTech.AspNet.Mvc.WebViewPageExtensions.RenderHeadWithoutJs(System.Web.Mvc.WebViewPage,GleamTech.AspNet.UI.Component,GleamTech.AspNet.UI.Component[])
member.summary: Renders the required resource tags except JS includes (only CSS includes etc.) for one or more GleamTech components. This method can be preferred when you want to render only CSS includes inside <head> tag and render only JS includes at the bottom of the page before before the closing </body> tag via calling . This practice of having CSS includes <head> and JS includes at the bottom before the closing </body> tag, is for increasing browser loading and rendering of your whole page; i.e. the user sees your page with your styles at first glance while the JS files are being loaded in the background. This method should be called inside <head> tag of the page. If you call this method inside <body> tag or some random place, the browser would misbehave. member.param: The instance.
The GleamTech component instance to render the head for.
Other GleamTech component instances to render the head for which are on the same page.
member.returns: The component resource tags that goes into <head> tag of the page.

member.name: M:GleamTech.AspNet.UI.ComponentRenderer.RenderHead(System.IO.TextWriter,GleamTech.AspNet.UI.Component,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Renders and writes to a TextWriter, the required resource tags (e.g. JS, CSS includes etc.) for a GleamTech component. This method should be called inside <head> tag of the page. If you call this method inside <body> tag or some random place, the browser would misbehave. Make sure you are not calling this method multiple times and adding the result to the same page HTML, for example including the same JS file multiple times in the same page would cause browser errors. Pass as true when you want to render only CSS includes inside <head> tag and render only JS includes at the bottom of the page before before the closing </body> tag via calling . This practice of having CSS includes <head> and JS includes at the bottom before the closing </body> tag, is for increasing browser loading and rendering of your whole page; i.e. the user sees your page with your styles at first glance while the JS files are being loaded in the background.
member.param: The TextWriter to write the component resource tags that goes into <head> tag of the page.
The GleamTech component instance to render the head for.
Whether to render JS includes or not.

member.name: T:GleamTech.AspNet.WebPages.WebPageExtensions
member.summary: Adds GleamTech related extensions methods to class for ASP.NET Web Pages (Razor, WebMatrix) support.

member.name: M:GleamTech.AspNet.WebPages.WebPageExtensions.RenderHead(System.Web.WebPages.WebPage,GleamTech.AspNet.UI.Component,GleamTech.AspNet.UI.Component[])
member.summary: Renders the required resource tags (e.g. JS, CSS includes etc.) for one or more GleamTech components. This method should be called inside <head> tag of the page. If you call this method inside <body> tag or some random place, the browser would misbehave. If you are rendering multiple GleamTech components in the same page, call this method once by passing all the component instances at once, this way the resources shared by all the components will be merged and included in the page once. Make sure you are not calling this method multiple times and adding the result to the same page HTML, for example including the same JS file multiple times in the same page would cause browser errors.
member.param: The instance.
The GleamTech component instance to render the head for.
Other GleamTech component instances to render the head for which are on the same page.
member.returns: The component resource tags that goes into <head> tag of the page.

member.name: M:GleamTech.AspNet.WebPages.WebPageExtensions.RenderHeadWithoutJs(System.Web.WebPages.WebPage,GleamTech.AspNet.UI.Component,GleamTech.AspNet.UI.Component[])
member.summary: Renders the required resource tags except JS includes (only CSS includes etc.) for one or more GleamTech components. This method can be preferred when you want to render only CSS includes inside <head> tag and render only JS includes at the bottom of the page before before the closing </body> tag via calling . This practice of having CSS includes <head> and JS includes at the bottom before the closing </body> tag, is for increasing browser loading and rendering of your whole page; i.e. the user sees your page with your styles at first glance while the JS files are being loaded in the background. This method should be called inside <head> tag of the page. If you call this method inside <body> tag or some random place, the browser would misbehave. If you are rendering multiple GleamTech components in the same page, call this method once by passing all the component instances at once, this way the resources shared by all the components will be merged and included in the page once. Make sure you are not calling this method multiple times and adding the result to the same page HTML, for example including the same JS file multiple times in the same page would cause browser errors.
member.param: The instance.
The GleamTech component instance to render the head for.
Other GleamTech component instances to render the head for which are on the same page.
member.returns: The component resource tags that goes into <head> tag of the page.

member.name: M:GleamTech.AspNet.WebPages.WebPageExtensions.RenderJs(System.Web.WebPages.WebPage,GleamTech.AspNet.UI.Component,GleamTech.AspNet.UI.Component[])
member.summary: Renders the required resource tags of JS includes (no CSS includes etc.) for one or more GleamTech components. This method can be preferred when you want to render only JS includes at the bottom of the page before before the closing </body> tag and render only CSS includes inside <head> tag via calling . This practice of having CSS includes <head> and JS includes at the bottom before the closing </body> tag, is for increasing browser loading and rendering of your whole page; i.e. the user sees your page with your styles at first glance while the JS files are being loaded in the background. This method should be called at the bottom of the page before before the closing </body> tag. If you call this method at some random place, the browser would misbehave. If you are rendering multiple GleamTech components in the same page, call this method once by passing all the component instances at once, this way the resources shared by all the components will be merged and included in the page once. Make sure you are not calling this method multiple times and adding the result to the same page HTML, for example including the same JS file multiple times in the same page would cause browser errors.
member.param: The instance.
The GleamTech component instance to render the JS includes for.
Other GleamTech component instances to render the JS includes for which are on the same page.
member.returns: The component resource tags that goes at the bottom of the page before before the closing </body> tag.

member.name: M:GleamTech.AspNet.WebPages.WebPageExtensions.RenderBody(System.Web.WebPages.WebPage,GleamTech.AspNet.UI.Component)
member.summary: Renders the actual body tags for a GleamTech component. This method should be called inside <body> tag (or child tags) of the page. If you call this method inside <head> tag or some random place, the browser would misbehave. If you are rendering multiple GleamTech components in the same page, this method can be called separately for each component.
member.param: The instance.
The GleamTech component instance to render the component body for.
member.returns: The component body tags that goes into <body> tag (or child tags) of the page.

member.summary: Gets the unique identifier for the location to store cached files.

member.name: P:GleamTech.Caching.FileCache.MaxAge
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that specifies the maximum amount of time to consider a cached item fresh and keep it stored in the cache. Cached items older than this age will be removed when the cache trimming (clean up) runs (when auto trim is run or when is manually called). The default value is 90 days.

member.name: P:GleamTech.Caching.FileCache.WaitTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that specifies the maximum amount of time to wait for a cached item to be available (wait for a file lock from other threads or processes to become available, i.e. wait for an ongoing caching of the same file to complete) before giving up on the cache request. The default value is 5 minutes.

member.name: P:GleamTech.Caching.FileCache.AutoTrimInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that specifies the interval to run automatic cache trimming (clean up). Cached items older than will be removed when the cache is trimmed. If the value is 0 or negative, the auto trim is disabled. The default value is 20 minutes.

member.name: M:GleamTech.Caching.FileCache.Trim
member.summary: Trims the cache (cleans up the expired cache items, i.e. cached items older than ).

member.name: P:GleamTech.FileProviders.DatabaseFileProvider.NameField
member.summary:
Gets or sets the field name for the file name in the table. Default value is null.
This could be a text based field (e.g. a nvarchar(100) field with file name values like "File.ext"). This field is optional, when it's available it's used by to provide more detailed file info. Note that uses file name part of as value when creating or overwriting the file.

member.name: P:GleamTech.FileProviders.DatabaseFileProvider.DateModifiedField
member.summary:
Gets or sets the field name for the file last modified date in the table. Default value is null.
This could be a datetime based field (e.g. a smalldatetime field). This field is optional, when it's available it's used by to provide more detailed file info. Note that uses as value when creating or overwriting the file.

member.name: P:GleamTech.FileProviders.DatabaseFileProvider.SizeField
member.summary:
Gets or sets the field name for the file size in the table. Default value is null.
This could be a number based field (e.g. a bigint field). This field is optional, when it's available it's used by to provide more detailed file info. Note that uses as value when creating or overwriting the file.

member.name: P:GleamTech.FileProviders.DatabaseFileProvider.ContentField
member.summary:
Gets or sets the field name for the file binary content in the table. Default value is "Content".
This could be a binary based field (e.g. a varbinary(max) field). This field is mandatory because and uses this field to read and write the file stream. Note that SQL Server supports streaming so binary large objects (BLOBs) can be read with using minimal memory, however other database providers may need to fully load the data into memory, resulting in memory overflow exceptions (e.g. files bigger than 2GB).

member.name: T:GleamTech.FileProviders.FileProvider
member.summary:
Represents a provider for handling files. Implement this class to provide a custom way of reading and/or writing files.
Values of this type can be set to:
A plain string which contains a physical/virtual path
(e.g. "c:\SomeFolder\SomeFile.ext", "/SomeFolder/SomeFile.ext", "~/SomeFolder/SomeFile.ext").
This is parsed as with . Note that virtual paths can only be resolved in a web application.
and on Linux paths starting with "/" are physical paths and not virtual paths.
A plain string which contains a URL.
(e.g. "http://example.com/SomeFolder/SomeFile.ext").
This is parsed as . HTTP and HTTPS (SSL) links are supported.
A instance created with one of the builtin file providers
(e.g. , , , , , , , ).
You can also override base class to implement your custom file provider.
A provider string which defines a specific file provider
(e.g. "Type=FileSystem; File=SomeFile.ext; Location='Type=Physical; Path=c:\SomeFolder'").

example.note: Below are the examples for setting a parameter/property.
example.para: Setting an Azure Blob file provider:
Setting an Amazon S3 file provider:
Setting a Data URL file provider:
Setting an assembly resource file provider:

member.name: P:GleamTech.FileProviders.FileProvider.CanSerialize
member.summary: Implement this property to indicate if a file with this provider can be serialized across processes and machines. For instance, a file on disk can be serialized because you only need path information to restore it but a file in memory is volatile, i.e. it cannot be restored on other machines. This property is mainly used by caching mechanisms, for deciding if a local copy of the file should be made. If the file is serializable, there will be no need for a local copy.
member.returns: true if this provider is volatile, false if not.

member.summary: Implement this method to provide a custom way of getting the information for the file. This method is called by . property should return true if this method is implemented and supported, should return false if not. This method should not return null and throw an exception if the file is not found or cannot be read.
member.returns: A instance initialized with the file information.

member.name: M:GleamTech.FileProviders.FileProvider.DoOpenRead
member.summary:
Implement this method to provide a custom way of opening a readable stream for the file. This method is called by . property should return true if this method is implemented and supported, should return false if not. This method should not return null and throw an exception if the file is not found or cannot be read.
Note that you can make use of builtin helper stream classes or when your logic needs control on disposing of an inner stream.
member.returns: A readable instance.

member.name: M:GleamTech.FileProviders.FileProvider.DoOpenWrite
member.summary:
Implement this method to provide a custom way of opening a writable stream for the file. This method is called by . property should return true if this method is implemented and supported, should return false if not. This method should not return null and throw an exception if the file cannot be created or written. If the file already exists, it should be overwritten.
Note that you can make use of builtin helper stream classes or when your logic needs control on disposing of an inner stream.
member.returns: A writable instance.

member.name: T:GleamTech.FileProviders.StreamFileProvider
member.summary: A file provider whose backing store is a stream. This provider supports both reading and writing files as long as the underlying stream does.

member.name: M:GleamTech.FileProviders.StreamFileProvider.#ctor(System.String,System.IO.Stream,System.Nullable{System.DateTime},System.Nullable{System.Int64})
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class for a specified file stored in a specified stream.
member.param:
The path of the file which defines the stream (virtual file).
e.g. "File.ext" or "SomeFolder\File.ext".
The stream containing the file. This class will dispose your stream when itself is disposed unless is set to true.

The time the file was last modified.
As streams do not provide time information, you can provide a specific dateModified to be used in . Specifying correct file information is important especially when this provider is used for caching, e.g. cache keys are generated from a string combination of file extension, file size and file date for uniquely identifying them, this way cache collisions do not occur and we can reuse the cached file even if the file name before extension is changed (because it's still the same file).

The size of the file.
If your stream is seekable, we can already get the size from property but if not you can provide a specific size to be used in . Specifying correct file information is important especially when this provider is used for caching, e.g. cache keys are generated from a string combination of file extension, file size and file date for uniquely identifying them, this way cache collisions do not occur and we can reuse the cached file even if the file name before extension is changed (because it's still the same file).

member.name: P:GleamTech.FileProviders.StreamFileProvider.TruncateAfterWrite
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that specifies whether to truncate the stream after each write (i.e. after ). This is useful when a smaller file is written on second file write, i.e. it will shrink the stream length. Note that this will work only if the stream is seekable and writable. This is parsed as .
Note that virtual paths can only be resolved in a web application
and on Linux paths starting with "/" are physical paths and not virtual paths.
A instance created with one of the builtin location providers
(e.g. , , , ).
You can also override base class to implement your custom location provider.
A provider string which defines a specific location provider
(e.g. "Type=Physical; Path=c:\SomeFolder").

member.name: M:GleamTech.GleamTechConfiguration.EnsureAssemblies
member.summary: Ensures GleamTech's assemblies are loaded and initialized. You may need to call this method in entry point/startup of your application, if you receive "Could not load file or assembly ..." errors. Some DLLs are embedded inside GleamTech's DLLs and they are resolved automatically when they are requested however internal AssemblyResolver should be initialized first and internal AssemblyResolver of each GleamTech DLL can be initialized only when a type inside that DLL is accessed first. So in some cases, even a GleamTech DLL is loaded, its AssemblyResolver may not be initialized yet (because none of its types is accessed yet). You can observe this behaviour if your application calls some methods which scans assemblies for reflection purpose (reflection-only type access does not trigger DLL's module initializer), for example ASP.NET Core's endpoints.MapControllers method and SimpleInjectors RegisterMvcControllers method. So to prevent errors on those methods, you can call this method before such methods. Note that you should not need to call this method usually for web applications, because it is handled automatically as we can know when the application is started by hooking up (automatically in ASP.NET Classic and when you call AddGleamTech and UseGleamTech methods in ASP.NET Core).

member.name: M:GleamTech.IO.TemporaryFolder.GetSystemTemporaryFolder
member.summary:
Gets the system temporary folder for GleamTech.
The default value is "[System Temporary Folder]\GleamTech".
[System Temporary Folder] can be different for different environments:
- For "ASP.NET Classic":
-- "%WINDIR%\Microsoft.NET\Framework64\v4.0.30319\Temporary ASP.NET Files\APPNAME\xxxxxxxx"
-- "%WINDIR%\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v4.0.30319\Temporary ASP.NET Files\APPNAME\xxxxxxxx" (if 32-bit AppPool)
-- "%LOCALAPPDATA%\Temp\Temporary ASP.NET Files\vs\xxxxxxxx" (when debugging in Visual Studio)
- For "ASP.NET Core" the path set in "ASPNETCORE_TEMP" environment variable or result of Path.GetTempPath which depends on "TMP", "TEMP" and "USERPROFILE" environment variables:
-- "%WINDIR%\Temp"
-- "%LOCALAPPDATA%\Temp" (if "Load User Profile" is enabled for AppPool in IIS)
- For Azure WebApp Service:
-- "D:\home" (%HOME% environment variable)
- For Console or other non-web apps, result of Path.GetTempPath which depends on "TMP", "TEMP" and "USERPROFILE" environment variables:
-- "%LOCALAPPDATA%\Temp"
-- "%WINDIR%\Temp"

member.name: M:GleamTech.IO.TemporaryFolder.GetSystemTemporaryPathContext

member.name: F:GleamTech.Security.LogonProvider.Default
member.summary: Use the standard logon provider for the system. The default security provider is negotiate, unless you pass NULL for the domain name and the user name is not in UPN format. In this case, the default provider is NTLM. NOTE: Windows 2000/NT: The default security provider is NTLM.

member.name: T:GleamTech.Security.LogonType
member.summary: Specifies the type of login used. http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/aa378184.aspx

member.name: F:GleamTech.Security.LogonType.Interactive
member.summary: This logon type is intended for users who will be interactively using the computer, such as a user being logged on by a terminal server, remote shell, or similar process. This logon type has the additional expense of caching logon information for disconnected operations; therefore, it is inappropriate for some client/server applications, such as a mail server.

member.name: F:GleamTech.Security.LogonType.Network
member.summary: This logon type is intended for high performance servers to authenticate plaintext passwords. The LogonUser function does not cache credentials for this logon type.

member.name: F:GleamTech.Security.LogonType.Batch
member.summary: This logon type is intended for batch servers, where processes may be executing on behalf of a user without their direct intervention. This type is also for higher performance servers that process many plaintext authentication attempts at a time, such as mail or web servers.

member.name: F:GleamTech.Security.LogonType.Service
member.summary: Indicates a service-type logon. The account provided must have the service privilege enabled.

member.name: F:GleamTech.Security.LogonType.Unlock
member.summary: GINAs are no longer supported. Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This logon type is for GINA DLLs that log on users who will be interactively using the computer. This logon type can generate a unique audit record that shows when the workstation was unlocked.

member.name: F:GleamTech.Security.LogonType.NetworkClearText
member.summary: This logon type preserves the name and password in the authentication package, which allows the server to make connections to other network servers while impersonating the client. A server can accept plaintext credentials from a client, call LogonUser, verify that the user can access the system across the network, and still communicate with other servers.

member.name: F:GleamTech.Security.LogonType.NewCredentials
member.summary: This logon type allows the caller to clone its current token and specify new credentials for outbound connections. The new logon session has the same local identifier but uses different credentials for other network connections. This logon type is supported only by the LOGON32_PROVIDER_WINNT50 logon provider.

NamedLock manages the lifetime of critical sections that can be accessed by a key (name) throughout the application. It also have some helper methods to allow a maximum wait time (timeout) to aquire the lock and safelly release it. Note: this nuget package contains c# source code and depends on System.Collections.Concurrent introduced in .Net 4.0.
